title: 115_s427
content: The "Social Security Expansion Act" includes provisions for an across-the-board benefit increase, computation of cost-of-living increases, an increase in minimum benefit for lifetime low earners, payroll tax adjustments, and taxes on self-employment earnings and investment gains. Section 215(a)(1)(B) of the Social Security Act is amended to increase benefits for individuals eligible for old-age or disability insurance after 2022. The increase starts at 1 percent in 2023 and gradually increases by 1 percentage point each year until 2036, with a steady increase from 2037 onwards. Starting in 2037, benefits will increase by 15 percent annually. SEC. 3. COMPUTATION OF COST-OF-LIVING INCREASES. The text discusses amending the Social Security Act to define the Consumer Price Index for Elderly Consumers (CPI-E) and its application to pre-1979 law. The Social Security Act is amended to include adjustments based on the Consumer Price Index for Elderly Consumers (CPI-E) and specifies that other laws providing for adjustments should be applied without regard to these amendments. The Bureau of Labor Statistics is tasked with preparing and publishing the CPI-E index. The Older Americans Amendments Act of 1987 authorizes the publication of the "Consumer Price Index for Elderly Consumers" starting from July of the year following the enactment of the Act. The amendments apply to cost-of-living computations ending on or after September 30 of the second year after the Act's enactment. Increase in minimum benefit for lifetime low earners based on years in the workforce. The amendment to the Social Security Act increases the minimum benefit for individuals eligible for old-age or disability insurance benefits after 2017. The minimum amount is based on years of work and ensures a certain level of monthly payment. The applicable percentage of the annual dollar amount is determined based on the number of years of work, as specified in a table. The applicable percentage of the annual dollar amount is determined based on the number of years of work, with percentages ranging from 6.25% to 68.75%. The annual dollar amount is determined based on the number of years of work, with percentages ranging from 6.25% to 125.00%. For calendar year 2018, the poverty guideline for 2017 is used, and for any year after 2018, the annual dollar amount is adjusted accordingly. The annual dollar amount for calendar years after 2018 is calculated based on the national average wage index ratio. The terms 'year of work' and 'poverty guideline for 2017' are defined within this context. The Department of Health and Human Services published regulations related to the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1981. The Commissioner of Social Security is required to recompute insurance amounts prior to November 2016. A conforming amendment was made to Section 209(k)(1) of the Social Security Act. SEC. 5. Payroll tax on remuneration up to contribution and benefit base and more than $250,000. Amends section 3121(a) of the Internal Revenue Code for calendar years when the contribution and benefit base is less than $250,000. Applies to remuneration paid after December 31, 2017. Tax on net earnings from self-employment up to contribution and benefit base and more than $250,000. The amendment to section 1402(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 calculates the tax on net earnings from self-employment exceeding the contribution and benefit base, minus wages paid to the individual during the taxable year. The amendment to section 1402(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 adjusts the tax calculation for self-employment earnings exceeding the contribution and benefit base, minus wages paid to the individual during the taxable year. The amendment applies to taxable years starting when the contribution and benefit base is under $250,000. Effective December 31, 2017, the changes affect self-employment earnings and remuneration. SEC. 7. TAX ON INVESTMENT GAIN. The tax rate in section 1411 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is increased from 3.8 percent to 10 percent. A new paragraph is added to the Social Security Act allocating 62 percent of these taxes to the Federal old-age and survivors insurance trust fund. The heading for chapter 2A of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include "AND SOCIAL SECURITY" after "MEDICARE." The amendments made by this section increase the tax rate in section 1411 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 from 3.8 percent to 10 percent. It also allocates 9 percent of these taxes to the Federal disability insurance trust fund. These changes apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2017.
